The commentary on the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha:
First, the Buddha's body is without error; second, his speech is without error; third, his mindfulness is without error;
Fourth, he is without different thoughts; fifth, he is without an undetermined mind; sixth, he is without unknowing and abandonment;

Seventh, his desires are without decrease; eighth, his diligence is without decrease; ninth, his mindfulness is without decrease; tenth, his wisdom is without decrease; eleventh, his liberation is without decrease; twelfth, his liberated insight is without decrease;
Thirteenth, all his physical actions follow the practice of wisdom; fourteenth, all his verbal actions follow the practice of wisdom; fifteenth, all his mental actions follow the practice of wisdom;
Sixteenth, the wisdom that knows the past unobstructed; seventeenth, the wisdom that knows the future unobstructed; eighteenth, the wisdom that knows the present unobstructed.
Question:
These thirty-six dharmas are all the Buddha's dharmas. Why are only the eighteen considered unshared?
Answer:
Among the first eighteen, the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas have a share, but among the last eighteen they have no share.
For example, ÅšÄriputra was able to analyze the dharmas and expound a single phrase with unobstructed understanding. The Buddha praised him, saying, You skillfully penetrate the nature of dharmas.
Aniruddha had the foremost heavenly eye. Such Å›rÄvakas all have a share.
As for the four forms of fearlessness, those who have a share are like the Buddha's disciples who are able to roar like lions. The foremost is Piá¹‡á¸ola-BhÄradvÄja.
ÅšÄriputra also vowed:

ÅšÄriputra, MaudgalyÄyana, PÅ«rá¹‡a, Ä€nanda, KÄtyÄyana, and others also know this meaning, names, language, and eloquence.
For this reason, the previous eighteen are not called uncommon.
Question:
Why does the Buddha have no bodily faults and no verbal faults?
Answer:
The Buddha, for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, has upheld pure precepts, so his bodily and verbal actions have no faults;
Other arhats such as ÅšÄriputra have practiced precepts for at most sixty kalpas, not for long, so they have faults.

The Buddha, for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, has accumulated pure precepts and accomplished them, always practiced profound meditation, attained all subtle wisdom, and well cultivated the mind of great compassion, so he has no faults.
Furthermore, because the Buddha has eradicated the root causes and conditions of all offenses, he has no faults.
There are four kinds of root causes and conditions for offenses:

First, the causes and conditions of greed and desire; second, the causes and conditions of anger and hatred; third, the causes and conditions of fear and terror; fourth, the causes and conditions of ignorance and delusion;
The Buddha has eradicated these root causes and conditions for offenses, as well as their habitual tendencies.
Although Arhats and Pratyekabuddhas have eradicated the causes of offenses, because their habitual tendencies are not completely exhausted, they may still occasionally make mistakes.
The Buddha, on the other hand, has perfected his wisdom that pervades all dharmas;
If he were to make mistakes due to ignorance, that would be a fault.

Once, ÅšÄriputra was traveling with five hundred bhiká¹£us to an empty temple to spend the night. It was the day for reciting the precepts, but they did not know the boundaries of the inner and outer areas. They reported this to the Buddha;
The Buddha said:
If you stay in a place even for one night, and then abandon it, there is no boundary.
Also, at another time, when ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana were leading five hundred bhiká¹£us back, they were making a loud noise, so the Buddha drove them out. This is a mistake of speech.
It is like ÅšÄriputra not knowing the rules for eating equally. The Buddha said:
You eat impure food!
In this way, there are mistakes of body and speech.
Because the Buddha has exhausted all afflictive habits, he does not have such mistakes.
Furthermore, because all the Buddha's bodily and verbal actions are in accordance with wisdom, his body is without mistake and his speech is without mistake.
For these various reasons, his body is without mistake and his speech is without mistake.
As for 'no loss of mindfulness,' it is because the four establishments of mindfulness have been well cultivated for a long time;
It is because he has well cultivated profound meditation, his mind is not scattered;
It is because he has well severed desire and attachment, and his mind is unattached to dharmas;
It is because he has attained the foremost state of mental peace.
If the mind is hurried and scattered, mindfulness will be lost;ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The Buddha's mind has no gains or losses, and for this reason there are no losses.

Furthermore, because the Buddha's supernormal knowledge, insight, and power are adorned and remembered in three ways, his mindfulness is accomplished without loss, and his mindfulness is mostly used in the past.
Furthermore, because the faculties and powers of mindfulness are boundless and inexhaustible, mindfulness is without loss.
Furthermore, because the Buddha's all mental activities follow wisdom, mindfulness is without loss;
because each thought follows mental activities.
These are called mindfulness without loss.
As the SÅ«tra of Heavenly Questions says:
Who is without faults?
Who does not lose mindfulness?
Who is always single-minded?
One who should do can do.
Correctly knowing all dharmas, liberated from all hindrances,
With all merits accomplished, there is only the Buddha alone!
As for no different thoughts, the Buddha has no discrimination towards all sentient beings, no distant or near different thoughts:
The noble can be taught, the lowly cannot be taught.
Just as the sun rises to illuminate all things, the Buddha's great compassionate light equally saves all with compassion:
The respectful and the disrespectful, enemies and friends, the noble and the lowly, all are the same.
Like the guest sweeper named NÄ«tha, the Buddha transformed and saved him, and he attained great arhatship.
Also like the householder Dhá¹›á¸habala, who wanted to harm the Buddha with a fire pit and poisoned food;
On that very day, he removed his three poisons and extinguished the fire of wrong views.
He had no different thoughts towards them.

Furthermore, the Buddha neither loved ÅšÄriputra, Maitreya Bodhisattva, and others who followed the Buddha's teachings, nor hated Devadatta, PÅ«raá¹‡a, and the six non-Buddhist teachers with wrong views.
This is because the Buddha cultivated and perfumed his mind for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, so he is a treasure among sentient beings, like true gold that cannot be changed.
Furthermore, the Buddha uses the Buddha eye to observe all sentient beings three times a day and night, to see who can be saved and not miss the right time;
Because he treats all sentient beings equally, he has no different thoughts.
Furthermore, the Buddha praises good dharmas with various reasons and reprimands bad dharmas with various reasons;
He also has no increase or decrease in his mind towards good and evil, but only makes distinctions for the sake of saving sentient beings, which is having no different thoughts.

Furthermore, as the Sutra of All Non-Practices says, The Buddha views all sentient beings as his own body, what he has done is accomplished, with no beginning, middle, or end, this is called having no different thoughts.
Furthermore, the Buddha observes all sentient beings and dharmas, from the beginning to the present, not arising or ceasing, always pure like nirvana, this is called having no different thoughts.
Furthermore, the gate of non-duality is the gate to the true nature of all dharmas;
The different characteristics are precisely the two dharmas, and the two dharmas are precisely the wrong path.
The Buddha is a person who does not deceive, and should not practice deceptive dharmas. He always practices the approach of non-duality.
Deceptive dharmas are precisely different characteristics.
These are called having no different thoughts.
Having no distracted mind means the mind is always in samÄdhi and not disturbed.
In a distracted mind, one cannot see the truth.
It is like water that is agitated and cannot see one's face, or like a lamp in the wind that cannot illuminate well.
For this reason, it is said that the Buddha has no distracted mind.
Question:
SamÄdhi is named from the stage of the preliminary concentration up to the concentration of cessation.
Entering these concentrations, one cannot perform bodily or verbal actions.

If the Buddha is always in samÄdhi and has no distracted mind, how can he travel to various countries, engage in the four modes of deportment, and expound the Dharma with various parables and causes and conditions for the great assembly?
Such a thing is possible for a mind bound to the desire realm and the Brahma world not entering concentration.
Answer:
No mind that is not in concentration has various meanings.
Concentration means always abiding with the mind dwelling in wholesome dharmas;
the Buddha is concentrated on the true characteristics of dharmas and does not regress, this is called no mind that is not in concentration.
Furthermore, there is concentration in the desire realm, entering this concentration one can expound the Dharma;

for this reason, the Abhidharma says that there are four noble lineages, four establishments of mindfulness, four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five strengths, the concentration of non-conflict, the knowledge of aspiration, and the four unobstructed understandings bound to the desire realm, with such wonderful merits.
Because the Buddha enters the concentration in the desire realm, it is called no mind that is not in concentration.
The Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, having arisen from concentration, if they enter a neutral mind, or enter wholesomeness, or regress and enter a defiled mind;

When the Buddha arises from concentration and enters the desire realm concentration, he never has a distracted mind at the beginning, and for this reason he is called one whose mind is never inattentive.
Furthermore, in the Å›rÄvaka teachings, a transformed person preaches the Dharma, but the transformer does not preach;
the transformer preaches, but the transformed person does not preach.
The Buddha is not like this. Both the transformed person and the transformer are able to preach the Dharma.
Concentration should also be different:
The Å›rÄvaka, when entering concentration, does not preach;
The Buddha, while in concentration, is able to preach the Dharma and also able to walk.
As the Miji jing (SÅ«tra of Secret Traces) says in the mind secret:
The Buddha's mind is always in concentration, and the mind should also preach the Dharma.
Furthermore, the distracted mind and dharmas, such as the bonds, attachments, doubts, and regrets, the Buddha is all without.
Although the arhat is without doubt in the four truths, everywhere in all dharmas there is doubt;
The Buddha, in all dharmas, is always in concentration without doubt, without inattentive wisdom.
Furthermore, the Å›rÄvakas have the habit energy of various afflictions, and therefore they have the dharma of regression and are scattered;
the Buddha, being replete with the wisdom of all wisdoms, is without distraction.
It is like a bottle filled with water, which then has no sound and no movement.
Furthermore, only the Buddha is called the Dharma of non-deception, the foremost among the three firm and solid people, whose mind does not change in the face of suffering and joy.

The characteristics of phenomena such as one characteristic and different characteristics, arising and ceasing, annihilation and permanence, coming and going - all such characteristics of phenomena are deceptive dharmas, because they are dharmas created by false combination.
Because the Buddha is established in the true characteristics of all dharmas, his mind is without uncertainty, and because there is no uncertainty, his mind does not change.
Furthermore, among the five inconceivable dharmas, the Buddha is the most inconceivable.
These eighteen distinctive qualities are the Buddha's most profound treasury - who can conceive of them!
For this reason, the Buddha has no uncertain mind, and this matter must surely be so.
Although the Buddha is always in samÄdhi, without the coarse mind of initial and sustained thought, he still has inconceivable wisdom and is therefore able to expound the Dharma.

It is like the heavenly music that accords with the preferences of the gods, producing various sounds. This also has no mind and no consciousness, but exists due to the karmic conditions of the gods' merit and virtue.
Just as heavenly music has no mind and no consciousness yet is able to accord with things, how much more so the Buddha who has a mind and does not expound the Dharma!
For this reason, it is said that the Buddha has no mind that is not in samÄdhi.
There is nothing that is not known and abandoned - sentient beings have three kinds of feelings:
painful feelings, pleasant feelings, and neither painful nor pleasant feelings.
Painful feelings give rise to anger, pleasant feelings give rise to craving, and neither painful nor pleasant feelings give rise to delusion.
These three kinds of feelings:
Painful feelings give rise to pain, abiding in pain, and the cessation of pain is pleasant;
Pleasant feelings give rise to pleasure, abiding in pleasure, and the cessation of pleasure is painful;
Neither painful nor pleasant feelings are not known as painful, and are not known as pleasant.

Other people, because of their dull faculties, mostly experience painful and pleasant feelings. Within the feeling of neither pain nor pleasure, they are unaware and do not know, and have a mind of indifference. This is being driven by the defilement of delusion.
The Buddha, within the feeling of neither pain nor pleasure, knows when the feeling arises, when it abides, and when it ceases.
For this reason, it is said that the Buddha has no mind of indifference that is not known.
Question:
What is indifference in this context?
Is it that neither pain nor pleasure itself is indifference?
Or is the indifference among the seven factors of awakening and the indifference among the four immeasurables called indifference?
Answer:
Neither pain nor pleasure itself is indifference, and the indifference in the two places is also indifference.
Why is it so?
Other people, within the feeling of neither pain nor pleasure, are unaware of the arising, abiding, and ceasing of each moment of thought, and only become aware after a long time.
The Buddha fully understands them all in each moment of thought.
Among the seven factors of enlightenment, if the mind is balanced and neither sunken nor agitated, then at that time one should be equanimous.
If it is sunken, one should cultivate the thought of vigor;
if it is agitated, one should cultivate the thought of concentration.
The Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas sometimes mistakenly concentrate the mind or become agitated, and then abandon it before it is balanced.
The Buddha knows in every moment of thought, whether coarse or subtle, deep or shallow, and having known, he is equanimous.
Question:
If that is so, why did the Buddha tell Nanda and the bhiká¹£us, When various feelings arise, Nanda knows they arise, when they abide, he knows they abide, when they cease, he knows they cease;
various thoughts and various perceptions are also like this?
Answer:
There are two kinds of perceptions:
First, perceiving within the mind, knowing the arising of painful feelings arises, knowing the abiding of painful feelings abides, knowing the cessation of painful feelings ceases;
knowing the arising of pleasant feelings arises, knowing the abiding of pleasant feelings abides, knowing the cessation of pleasant feelings ceases;
The same is true for neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings.
One can only know this general characteristic, not the specific characteristics.
Second, within each moment of painful, pleasant, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings, one fully awakens and fully knows;
In each moment of the mental factors, there is nothing that is not known.
For this reason, it is said that the Buddha does not abandon anything without knowing it.
Furthermore, the Buddha sometimes abandons sentient beings and enters profound concentration for a month or two.
Some people doubt:
The Buddha appears in the world to deliver sentient beings, so why does he always enter concentration?
The Buddha said:
I abandon [sentient beings] because I know the various causes and conditions, not because I abandon them without knowing.
Question:
What are the causes and conditions for knowing and then abandoning?
Answer:
It is because of weariness in the great assembly that one rests for a short while.
Furthermore, the Buddha has always loved the practice of seclusion throughout his lifetimes.
If a bodhisattva is in his mother's womb, the mother also delights in practicing far-away dhyÄna, forty li away from the city, in the forest of RÄmagrÄma;
when attaining the Way, in the forest of UruvilvÄ, alone under a tree, becoming a Buddha;
when first turning the wheel of the Dharma, also in the forest where sages dwell, in the deer park;
when entering nirvÄá¹‡a, in the forest of ÅšÄla trees, under the twin trees.
For a long time delighting in practicing far-away dhyÄna, for this reason the Buddha enters dhyÄna concentration.
Moreover, the Buddha always accomplishes the mind of abandonment, therefore he enters dhyÄna concentration.

Moreover, the Buddha is far away from the places of confusion and mixed speech, also personally contemplates the treasury of merits of all Buddhas, also receives the foremost pure bliss, therefore he enters dhyÄna concentration.
Moreover, after the Buddha has expounded the Dharma, he always teaches the bhiká¹£us to sit in dhyÄna, not to regret later.
What is spoken by the mouth, the body also practices itself, therefore he enters dhyÄna concentration.
Furthermore, in order to detest offerings, knowing that sentient beings who should be liberated enter meditation and transform into people to go and liberate them.
Furthermore, there are sentient beings with little concentration and much wisdom, so the body demonstrates practicing meditation to teach and transform them.
Furthermore, some people give rise to thoughts of disgust upon seeing the Buddha, so they slightly distance themselves, causing them to be hungry and thirsty.
Furthermore, the Buddha wishes to speak the Dharma for the devas, so he is in a secluded place.
Furthermore, the Buddha sits in meditation in order to create the Dharma for future generations.
Moreover, after the Buddha has turned the Dharma wheel, he enters meditation in order to entrust the matter to his disciples.
Furthermore, in order to gather sentient beings through manifesting the two kinds of paths:
First, concentration, and second, wisdom.
When the Buddha speaks the Dharma in the great assembly, he manifests wisdom;
When he is in a quiet place and focuses his mind, he manifests concentration.
Furthermore, sentient beings have three kinds of practices within the six sense objects:
Seeing good forms gives rise to joy and pleasure, seeing bad forms gives rise to sorrow and suffering, seeing neither suffering nor pleasure gives rise to a mind of equanimity;
up to the same is true for dharmas.
The Buddha is sovereign among the six sense objects, and is able to give rise to a mind of equanimity in places of joy, pleasure, and suffering, as explained in the Noble Supernatural Powers.
For these and other various reasons he enters meditative concentration, not because he does not know and abandons [afflictions].
Desire is not diminished means that because the Buddha knows the kindness of wholesome dharmas, he always desires to accumulate all wholesome dharmas, so his desire is not diminished.
Cultivating all wholesome dharmas, his mind is never content, so his desire is not diminished.
For example, there was an elder bhiká¹£u who was blind and was sewing his saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« robe himself, when the needle broke.
He said to the people:
Who desires to create merit and virtue? Thread my needle for me.
At that time, the Buddha appeared before him and said:
I am a person who desires to create merit and virtue without being content. Bring me your needle.
This bhiká¹£u, seeing the Buddha's radiance and recognizing the sound of the Buddha, said to the Buddha:
The Buddha's immeasurable ocean of merit has all reached its end, so why is there no satisfaction?
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£u:
The retribution of merit is profound, and there is no one who knows the extent of my gratitude like me;
Although I have reached the end of it, it is because my original desire was insatiable that I attained Buddhahood, and therefore I am still not at rest now;
Although there is no more merit to be obtained, my desire is still not ceased!
The devas and humans of the world were startled and enlightened, thinking that if the Buddha was still not satisfied with his merit, how much more so would other people be?
The Buddha expounded the Dharma for the bhiká¹£u, and at that time his fleshly eyes became clear and his wisdom eye was accomplished.
Question:
Since the Buddha once cut off all desires for good dharmas, why is it said now that desire is not diminished?
Answer:
As for cutting off all desires for good dharmas, this refers to the desire to obtain what has not yet been obtained, and the desire to increase what has already been obtained;
The Buddha has no such desires.
The Buddha's merits and virtues are all complete, there is nothing he has not obtained, and there is nothing to be further increased.
As for the word desire now, it is as explained before:
Although the Buddha has fully obtained all merits and virtues, his desirous mind still does not cease.
It is like the divine horse, even though it has reached its destination, its desire to go does not cease, until it dies;
The Buddha-jewel is also like this.
Moreover, it is like the great fire at the end of the eon, burning up the entire trichiliocosm, and the power of the fire does not cease;
The Buddha's wisdom fire is also like this, burning up all afflictions, and after illuminating all dharmas, the desire associated with wisdom is also not exhausted.
Furthermore, although the Buddha's merits and virtues are all complete, he still desires to liberate beings without ceasing because they are not yet exhausted.
Question:
If the Buddha wishes to save sentient beings and has not yet ceased, why does he enter nirvana?
Answer:
There are two kinds of saving sentient beings:
Some are saved in the present, and some are saved after the Buddha's extinction.
As it is said in the Lotus Sutra, The medicine master combines medicine for the children and gives it to them, and then leaves. Therefore, he enters nirvana.

Furthermore, there are sentient beings with dull faculties and little virtue, who are unable to accomplish great things but can only plant the causes and conditions of blessings and virtue. Therefore, he enters nirvana.
Question:
Even after the Buddha's nirvana, there are those who attain arhatship. Why is it said that they can only plant the causes and conditions of blessings and virtue?
Answer:
Although there are those who attain arhatship, they are few and not worth mentioning.
When the Buddha expounds the Dharma once, immeasurable sentient beings in the ten directions attain the Way. It is not so after the Buddha's nirvana.
It is like a great country going to war. Although there are some gains, it is not considered a gain.
For this reason, although sentient beings are not yet exhausted, [the Buddha] enters nirvana.
Furthermore, the MahÄyÄna ÅšÅ«raá¹ƒgama-sÅ«tra states:
The Buddha, in the world of adornment, lived for seven hundred asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, liberating sentient beings.
For this reason, it is said that the Buddha's desire is not diminished.
As for vigor is not diminished, as explained in the section on desire,
the meaning of desire is precisely vigor.
Question:
If that is so, then there are no eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha.
Furthermore, desire and vigor are distinct mental factors. How can it be said that desire is precisely vigor?
Answer:
Desire is the initial practice, and the growth of desire is called vigor.
As the Buddha said:
All dharmas have desire as their foundation.
Desire is like a thirsty person wanting to drink, and vigor is like seeking to drink through expedient means.
Desire is the desire in the mind to obtain, and vigor is the accomplishment of that matter.
Desire belongs to the mental actions, and vigor belongs to the three actions.
Desire is internal, and vigor is external.
There are such distinctions.
Moreover, this vigor is what the Buddhas delight in. By the power of vigor, ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha surpassed nine kalpas and quickly attained supreme perfect enlightenment.
Furthermore, it is said:
Once, the Buddha told Ä€nanda:
You should expound the Dharma for the bhiká¹£us. I have a backache and will rest for a while.
At that time, the World-Honored One folded his uttarÄsaá¹…ga robe into four layers and lay down with his head on the saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« robe.
At that time, when Ä€nanda was expounding the seven factors of enlightenment, when he reached the factor of vigor, the Buddha suddenly sat up and told Ä€nanda:
Are you praising the meaning of vigor?
Ä€nanda said:
I am praising it.
This happened three times.
The Buddha said:
Excellent!
Excellent!
You have well cultivated diligence, and have attained anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, let alone other paths!
For this reason, the Buddha's diligence is not diminished. Even when sick, he still does not rest, let alone when not sick.

Moreover, in order to deliver sentient beings, the Buddha abandons the bliss of profound dhyÄna concentration, and with various bodies, various languages, and various skillful means, he delivers sentient beings.
Sometimes he encounters dangerous paths;
sometimes he eats bad food;
sometimes he experiences cold and heat;
sometimes he encounters various difficulties and harsh words, enduring them without weariness.
Although the World-Honored Buddha has mastery over all dharmas, he still engages in these activities without giving rise to laziness.
Just as the Buddha, after delivering sentient beings, lay down between the twin Å›Äla trees in the SÄla Grove.
The brÄhman Subhadra said to Ä€nanda:
I have heard that the omniscient one will attain parinirvÄá¹‡a tonight. I wish to see the Buddha!
Ä€nanda stopped him, saying:
The Buddha has been expounding the Dharma extensively for the multitude, and he is exhausted!
The Buddha heard from afar and told Ä€nanda:
Let Subhadra enter. He is my last disciple.

Subhadra was allowed to enter, asked the Buddha about his doubts, and the Buddha expounded the Dharma according to his wishes, resolving his doubts and enabling him to attain the Way. Before the Buddha entered parinirvÄá¹‡a without remainder,
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
It is extremely rare!
You have compassion for the non-Buddhist brÄhmaá¹‡as until the very end, and you have spoken with them.
The Buddha said:
I not only save them at the very end in this life, but also at the very end in previous lives before attaining the Way.

In the past, immeasurable and incalculable eons ago, there was a large forest with many birds and beasts. A wild fire came and burned on three sides, leaving only one side separated by a body of water. The beasts were in a desperate situation, with no place to escape.

At that time, I was a deer with a large body and great strength. With my front legs on one bank and my hind legs on the other bank, I allowed the herd of animals to step on my back and cross over. My skin and flesh were completely destroyed, but out of compassion, I endured it to the death.
The last rabbit came, and my strength was already exhausted. I mustered my strength and endured it, allowing it to cross over.
After it crossed, my back broke and I fell into the water and died.
This has been going on for a long time, not just now.
Those who were saved before are now my disciples;
The last rabbit is Subhadra.
The Buddha joyfully practiced diligently life after life, and even now he has not stopped. Therefore, it is said diligence is not diminished.
Mindfulness is not diminished means that because [the Buddha] is associated with the wisdom of all dharmas in the three times, his mindfulness is complete and not diminished.
Question:
Previously, it was already said mindfulness is without loss, and now it is said again mindfulness is not diminished.
Unfailing mindfulness and unreduced mindfulness - are they one?ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
Are mindfulness without loss and mindfulness without decrease the same or different?
If they are the same, why is it said twice?
If they are different, what is the difference?
The answer is:
Loss of mindfulness refers to mistakes;
Decrease refers to insufficiency.
Loss of mindfulness refers to losing mindfulness in the Dharma of bowing and looking up, coming and going;
Without decrease refers to abiding in meditation and spiritual powers, with mindfulness of the past and present unobstructed and penetrating.
The question is:
Why is mindfulness without decrease unique to the Buddha's teachings?
The answer is:
Because Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas cultivate the four establishments of mindfulness well, their mindfulness is firm;
Although their mindfulness is firm, it still decreases and is obstructed and not penetrating.
As it is said in the power of knowledge of past abodes:
For Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, the recollection of past lives is at most eighty thousand eons, with decrease in the extensive.
Also, within the path of seeing the truth, one is unable to discern moment by moment.

The Buddha discerns the three characteristics in every moment of thought. There is not a single dharma that the Buddha does not contemplate. For this reason, only the Buddha's mindfulness is without decrease.
Furthermore, the power of knowledge of past abodes is known through recollection. The Buddha has power in this.
Even Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas do not have this power of mindfulness, let alone other people.
Furthermore, the Buddha is guarded and mindful with unobstructed omniscience. For this reason, there is no decrease.
For these and other causes and conditions, the Buddha's mindfulness is without decrease.
Wisdom without decrease means that because the Buddha has attained all wisdom, his wisdom is without decrease.
Because his wisdom of the three times is unobstructed, his wisdom is without decrease.
Furthermore, because he has accomplished the ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, and the four unobstructed understandings, his wisdom is without decrease.
Furthermore, it is like how when ghee and oil are abundant and the wick is pure, the light is also strong;

The Buddha is also like this. The oil of various samÄdhis such as the king of samÄdhis and the wick of undiminished pure mindfulness are the causes and conditions. Therefore, the light of wisdom is immeasurable and undiminished.

Furthermore, from the initial arousal of the mind for an incalculably long time, accumulating all wisdom, with a sincere mind for the sake of the Dharma, giving away one's head, eyes, marrow, and brain, all internal and external possessions, and practicing generosity;

Entering fire, throwing oneself off a cliff, flaying one's skin, nailing one's body, and so on, suffering no hardship without experiencing it, with a single mind accumulating wisdom, wisdom is undiminished.
Furthermore, the Buddha's wisdom is accomplished by assisting with all merits, precepts, and dhyÄna concentrations, and therefore wisdom is undiminished.

Furthermore, seeking all scriptures and treatises in life after life, worldly and Buddhist teachings, coarse and fine, good and bad, all of which are studied and understood, and therefore wisdom is undiminished.
Furthermore, because of hearing the Dharma, reading and reciting, contemplating, cultivating, and asking questions from the innumerable Buddhas of the ten directions, wisdom is not diminished.
Furthermore, for the sake of all sentient beings, in order to increase all wholesome dharmas, and to destroy ignorance everywhere, wisdom is not diminished.
Furthermore, this wisdom truly knows the characteristics of dharmas as unborn and unceasing, not pure and not defiled, without action and without practice;
It does not discriminate this as wisdom or not wisdom, knowing that all dharmas are the same, pure like empty space, without defilement and attachment;

It does not attain the characteristics of the non-dual entrance by means of the two dharmas. The characteristics of the non-dual entrance are immeasurable and boundless. For this reason, wisdom is not diminished.
For these various reasons, wisdom is not diminished.ğŸ”½The diminution of liberation means there are two kinds of liberation:
conditioned liberation and unconditioned liberation.
The conditioned liberation is called liberation associated with pure wisdom, and the unconditioned liberation is called the complete and utter extinction of all afflictions without remainder.
The Buddha has no diminution in the two liberations.
Why is this?
Because the wisdom of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas is not very sharp, and because they have not completely extinguished the afflictions, their wisdom has diminution;
Because the Buddha's wisdom is the sharpest, and because he has completely extinguished the afflictions without remainder, his liberation has no diminution.
Furthermore, as explained in the power of the extinction of defilements, there is a distinction between the Buddha's liberation and that of the Å›rÄvakas.
Because the Buddha has attained the power of the extinction of defilements, his liberation has no diminution;
Because the two vehicles lack this power, they have diminution.

As for the diminution of the knowledge and vision of liberation, because the Buddha's wisdom is immeasurable, boundless, and pure within all liberations, it is called the diminution of the knowledge and vision of liberation.
Question:
Since the Buddha has no diminution in all dharmas, why is it only in these six matters that he has no diminution?
Answer:
Among all self-benefit and benefiting others, the four things can be fully possessed:
Desire is the root of seeking all good dharmas;
Diligence is being able to practice;
Mindfulness is being able to guard, like a gatekeeper who lets in the good and blocks the bad;
Wisdom illuminates all dharma gates and cuts off all afflictions.
Using these four dharmas, affairs can be accomplished.
The fruits and rewards of these four dharmas are of two kinds:
First, liberation; second, the knowledge and insight of liberation.
The meaning of liberation is as explained above.
As for the knowledge and insight of liberation, it is precisely the knowledge and insight of liberation, knowing the characteristics of these two kinds of liberation:
Liberation with form and liberation without form.

Knowing the characteristics of various liberations, namely timely liberation, non-timely liberation, liberation through wisdom, liberation through both, destroyed liberation, indestructible liberation, the eight liberations, inconceivable liberation, unobstructed liberation, and so forth.
Discerning the characteristics of various liberations, whether firm or not, is called the perfection of knowledge and insight.
As in the mindfulness of the Buddha, the Buddha accomplishes the five assemblies of the adepts;
The assembly of knowledge and insight should be explained in detail here.
Question:
As for knowledge and insight, why is seeing mentioned again, when it is already said knowing?
Answer:
Saying knowing and seeing makes the matter more solid;
It is like two ropes twisted into one, which is more solid.
Furthermore, if only knowing is mentioned, then it does not include all wisdom.
As the Abhidharma says:
There are three kinds of wisdom:
There is knowledge that is not seeing, there is seeing that is not knowledge, and there is that which is both knowledge and seeing.
Knowledge that is not seeing refers to the knowledge associated with the cognition of exhaustion, the cognition of non-arising, and the five consciousnesses.
Seeing that is not knowledge refers to the eight forbearances, worldly right view, and the five wrong views.
That which is both knowledge and seeing refers to the remaining wisdoms.
If one speaks of knowledge, then seeing is not included. If one speaks of seeing, then knowledge is not included. Therefore, speaking of both knowledge and seeing is complete.
Furthermore, reciting and reading from others and discriminating and contemplating is called knowledge;
personally attaining realization is called seeing.
For example, hearing about a matter with the ears still has doubts, which is called knowledge;
personally witnessing it with one's own eyes, clearly without doubt, is called seeing.
The distinction between knowledge and seeing in liberation is also like this.
Furthermore, some people say:
The arhats themselves have doubts about their liberation and cannot ascertain whether they are arhats or not.
Therefore, the Buddha, in order to eliminate such wrong views, says that the sages also know and see within liberation.
Although the arhats have attained the knowledge and vision of liberation, the knowledge and vision of liberation has diminished for them:

Because they have not attained omniscience, because the faculty of supreme wisdom is not perfected, and because they do not know the specific characteristics of the arising and ceasing of dharmas moment by moment.

The Buddha, because he has perfected the faculty of supreme wisdom and knows the arising and ceasing of the specific characteristics of dharmas moment by moment, has no diminution in the knowledge and vision of liberation.
Furthermore, because the Dharma eye is pure and fully accomplished, as explained in the meaning of the Dharma eye.

Knowing that this sentient being enters nirvana through the gate of liberation of emptiness, this sentient being enters nirvana through the gate of liberation of signlessness, and this sentient being enters nirvana through the gate of liberation of wishlessness;
Knowing that this sentient being observes the gate of the five aggregates, the twelve sense bases, and the eighteen elements, and attains liberation through such various Dharma gates.
The Buddha fully knows and understands all liberations and insights, and therefore it is said that the Buddha's liberations and insights are without diminution.

All bodily actions, all verbal actions, and all mental actions are in accordance with wisdom means that the Buddha's all bodily, verbal, and mental actions are known beforehand and then carried out in accordance with wisdom.

The bodily, verbal, and mental actions of the Buddhas, all practices are for the benefit of sentient beings, and therefore it is said that they are known beforehand and then carried out in accordance with wisdom.
As it is said in the sutra:
The buddhas, even their exhalation and inhalation of breath, benefit sentient beings, let alone their bodily, verbal, and mental actions, which are all done with the intention to benefit!
Even evil and hateful sentient beings, upon smelling the fragrance of the Buddha's exhalation and inhalation, all attain faith and purity, and come to love and respect the Buddha;
The devas, upon smelling the fragrance of the Buddha's breath, also all abandon the five desires and give rise to the aspiration to cultivate goodness.
For this reason, it is said that the Buddha's bodily, verbal, and mental actions are in accord with wisdom.
The Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas do not have this.
The mind first does good, and then the bodily and verbal actions are good;
The mental action may sometimes be indeterminate, not in accord with wisdom and arising by itself, let alone other people!
Like the bhiká¹£u GavÄá¹ƒpati, although he attained arhatship, he would eat and then vomit up his food to eat again. This action was not in accord with wisdom.
Also like the bhiká¹£u MaudgalyÄyana, an arhat, who would jump onto a rafter, or onto a wall or a tree.
It is also like Pilindavatsa scolding the river god, saying:
Little maid!
In this way, his physical and verbal actions were not preceded by wisdom, nor did he act in accordance with wisdom.
The Buddha does not have these things.
Question:
If that is so, then sometimes the Buddha's physical and verbal actions also seem to not be in accordance with wisdom.
Why is this?
When entering the assembly of non-Buddhists to expound the Dharma, there were none who believed and accepted it.
Moreover, at one time, while expounding the Dharma in the great assembly, he bared his chest to show the Nirgrantha Jains.
Furthermore, in order to dispel people's doubts about the two marks, he manifested the tongue and sexual organ in the great assembly.
Moreover, he scolded his disciples, saying:
You crazy and foolish people!
He scolded Devadatta, saying:
You are a crazy person, a dead person, a person who coughs and spits!
The Buddha established the precept that the eight types of bowls should not be kept, and allowed the monks to use two types of bowls:
He used a stone bowl himself.
Sometimes when faced with difficult questions from non-Buddhists, the Buddha remained silent and did not answer.
Moreover, the Buddha spoke of the existence of a self in some places and of the non-existence of a self in other places;
He spoke of the existence of dharmas in some places and of the non-existence of dharmas in other places.
In this way, his bodily and verbal actions seem not to accord with wisdom.
Since bodily and verbal actions are not separate from mental actions, mental actions should also not accord with wisdom. How can it be said that they always accord with wisdom?
Answer:
This is not so!
In all these matters, there is wisdom first, and then the various actions accord with wisdom.
Why is this?
The Buddha entered the assembly of non-Buddhists, although knowing that they would not believe or accept in this life, he did so to plant great causes and conditions for the future.
Moreover, in order to stop the non-Buddhists from slandering the Buddha, saying he was arrogant, he went himself to enter their assembly.
Moreover, the non-Buddhists said:
The Buddha himself says he has great compassion and universally saves all, yet he only teaches the Dharma for the four assemblies. We have also left home to seek the Way, yet he does not teach us!
Moreover, in this sutra, the Buddha goes to the assembly of non-Buddhists and teaches the Dharma, not saying they do not believe and accept it.
The Buddha saw from afar the great assembly of non-Buddhists debating in loud voices, and wanted to go elsewhere, but turned back towards them.
The debaters saw the Buddha coming from afar and said to their assembly:
You all be silent!
The Buddha is a person who delights in tranquility. Seeing you all silent, he may come here.
The assembly immediately fell silent.
The Buddha entered their assembly and spoke the three truths of the Brahmins. The assembly of non-Buddhists all fell silent.
The Buddha thought:
These mad people are all covered by the evil Mara;
this Dharma is subtle, and not a single person is willing to become a disciple.
Having had this thought, he left his seat and departed.
This person, being freed from the demon's obstruction, then thinks to himself:
We have heard the wonderful Dharma, why not benefit ourselves?
They all go to where the Buddha is, become the Buddha's disciples, attain the Way, and leave suffering.
Furthermore, the disciples of non-Buddhist paths dare not go to where the Buddha is because they find fault with their teachers, therefore the Buddha himself enters their assemblies.
The assembly hears the Dharma, believes and accepts it firmly, no longer finds fault with their teachers, becomes disciples, and attains the Way.
There are various kinds of wisdom causes and conditions like this, therefore he goes and enters the assemblies of non-Buddhist paths.
Furthermore, the Nirgrantha Jains of PÄá¹­aliputra wrapped copper around their bellies and vowed:
No one can withstand my arguments without sweating and breaking down!
Even great elephants, trees, tiles, and stones, upon hearing my arguments, will all sweat!
Having made this vow, they came to where the Buddha was and debated with the Buddha.
The Buddha questioned them, but none could answer. Sweat flowed from their bodies and soaked the ground, as if they were immersed in water.
The Buddha told Nirgrantha:
You previously vowed that no one who hears my questions will be able to avoid sweating. Now your sweat flows and soaks the ground.
You should observe the Buddha and see if he has any signs of sweating.
The Buddha then removed his uttarÄsaá¹…ga robe and showed it to them, saying:
Where is the sweat?
Next, some people said:
Some people sweat on the head but not on the body. Although the Buddha's head does not sweat, his body must have sweat.
For this reason, the Buddha removed his uttarÄsaá¹…ga robe and showed his body;
Because of this, the non-Buddhists greatly gained faith and all entered the Buddha's teachings.
This is the physical action that follows the practice due to the cause and condition of wisdom.

As for the Buddha manifesting the tongue and the hidden organ, some people doubted the Buddha's two physical characteristics. Although this person should have attained the Way, he could not because of his doubts. For this reason, the Buddha manifested his two characteristics.
The tongue covered the face, and although the tongue was large, it still fit back into the mouth without obstruction, causing the viewers to doubt.
Some people saw the tongue emerge and gave rise to a disrespectful mind, thinking the tongue was like a child's.
Seeing it fit back into the mouth without obstructing the Buddha's speech, they then gave rise to respect and praised it as unprecedented!
Some people doubted that the Buddha's hidden male organ was not visible, so at that time the World-Honored One transformed into a jeweled elephant and horse, pointing out, saying:
The hidden male organ is not visible, just like this.
Some people said:
The Buddha only revealed his hidden male organ to one person, in order to cut off their doubts.
The debaters said:

The Buddha has a mind of great compassion. If there are people who see the Buddha's hidden male organ and are able to accumulate wholesome roots, give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, and give rise to a mind of great joy and reverence, he will allow them all to see it, cutting off their doubting minds;
Except for these, no one can see it.
The Buddha, out of great compassion, in order to save sentient beings, emerged from the three kinds of concealment, temporarily appearing like a flash of lightning;
When these sentient beings saw this, they believed that the Buddha had a mind of great compassion, and truly did not grasp or cling to the precepts.
For these and other causes and conditions, he manifested the two appearances, not out of playfulness or shamelessness.
The Buddha sternly spoke to the bhiká¹£us, calling you mad and foolish people. Stern words are of two kinds:
First, with a defiled mind, one scolds out of anger; second, out of compassion for sentient beings, one wishes to teach and transform them.
One who is free from desire has no defiled mind to scold, let alone the Buddha!
The Buddha has stern words out of compassion and teaching.
There are sentient beings who, when gently spoken to and well taught, do not enter the path. They must be sternly and roughly taught before they can enter the Dharma.
It is like a fine horse that goes upon seeing the shadow of the whip, while a stubborn donkey only moves when struck with pain.
It is also like a wound that can be healed by soft medicine, saliva, and spells;
there are wounds that can only be healed by cutting out the bad flesh with a knife and applying bad medicine.
Furthermore, there are five kinds of harsh words:
1. mere frivolous speech;
2. abusive speech and frivolous speech;
3. abusive speech, frivolous speech, and false speech;
4. abusive speech, frivolous speech, false speech, and divisive speech;
5. harsh words spoken without afflictions:
in order to teach disciples to distinguish good and bad dharmas, and to rescue sentient beings from the land of suffering and difficulty.
One who possesses all four kinds of evil speech has the heaviest offense;
three, two, or one, it becomes gradually lighter.
The Buddha's lay disciples who have attained the first or second path, even if they have abusive speech towards their servants, it is not an unwholesome path.
There are two kinds of precepts for restraining oneself:
frivolous speech, or abusive speech and frivolous speech.
AnÄgÄmins and arhats do not give rise to afflictions and harsh speech, but only use pure thoughts and harsh words to teach and transform, thus [they have] harsh speech and frivolous speech.
AnÄgÄmins and arhats do not even give rise to afflictions and harsh speech, let alone the Buddha!
Moreover, if the Buddha had any harsh words, one should not doubt or question them, saying the Buddha spoke harsh words with an evil mind.
Why is this?

The Buddha long ago extinguished evil thoughts, but only deeply thinks of sentient beings, like a kind father teaching his son. Although he may use harsh words, it is to accomplish the son, not out of evil thoughts.

When the Buddha was a bodhisattva, before exhausting the three poisons, he was a sage named Ká¹£ÄntivÄdi. The evil king cut off his ears, nose, hands, and feet, but he did not give rise to evil thoughts or speak evil words.

At that time, he had not yet attained the Way, and still had no evil thoughts, let alone having attained supreme perfect enlightenment, with the three poisons exhausted, and being fully endowed with great kindness and compassion towards all beings. How could he doubt that the Buddha has an evil mind and harsh words?
Furthermore, if the Buddha says mad and foolish person, this is soft speech and truthful speech.
Why is it so?
Because the three poisons arise, it is called mad and foolish.
Also, because of benefiting with good things but being unwilling to accept them, not understanding the Buddha's mind and not accepting the Buddha's words, this is being mad and foolish.
Furthermore, the Buddha always practices the wisdom of non-self internally and always observes the emptiness of all dharmas externally. How could one like this have evil speech?
These beings do not understand the Buddha's mind, so they seek faults in the Buddha's words;

If sentient beings understand that the Buddha deeply sympathizes with them, even if he were to teach them to enter a great fire, they would joyfully enter it immediately, just as a person who is hot and exhausted enters a cool pond, let alone just words that they would not accept?
Sentient beings are covered by evil mÄras and therefore do not know that the Buddha deeply thinks of them, and thus they do not accept the Buddha's words;
for this reason, the Buddha says you are a deluded and foolish person.
Furthermore, some people, upon hearing harsh words, joyfully say:
Because you love me, you speak like this!
For this reason, the Buddha says you are a deluded and foolish person.
The Buddha said to Devadatta:
You are a crazy person, a dead person, a person who spits.
As for crazy person, because Devadatta's offenses are grave and he will enter AvÄ«ci Hell, the Buddha uses three kinds of harsh words.

As for dead person, it means someone who resembles a person but is unable to accumulate wholesome dharmas. Also, because Devadatta shaved his head and wore the Dharma robes, appearing like a sage, but inwardly lacking the wisdom-life, he is called a dead person.
Just as a dead person, no matter how much they are adorned, will only become increasingly rotten and never be able to be revived.

It is the same with Devadatta. Even though the Buddha taught and transformed him in various ways every day, his evil mind became increasingly intense, and his unwholesome and unskillful dharmas increased day by day, until he committed the three offenses with immediate retribution. For this reason, he is called a dead person.

As for spitting person, because Devadatta greedily sought offerings, he transformed himself into the body of a young child and was held in the lap of King AjÄtaÅ›atru. The king kissed his mouth and made him spit. For this reason, he is called a spitting person.
Question:
Devadatta attained meditative concentration and had already become free from desire. How could he then spit on others?
Answer:
This person's evil mind is also deep, and his faculties are also sharp;

Because of being free from desires, one can transform, but when spitting, one loses [the ability to transform]. Because of having sharp faculties, when seeking, one immediately obtains. For this reason, it is called 'spitting person'.
The meaning of 'mad' is as explained above.
Moreover, Devadatta said to the Buddha:
The Buddha is already old and always enjoys tranquility. He can enter the forest to amuse himself with meditation. The Sangha can be entrusted to me!
The Buddha said:

ÅšÄriputra, MaudgalyÄyana, and others have great wisdom and are good, gentle, and pure people. I would not even entrust the Sangha to them, let alone to you, a mad person, a dead person, a spitting person!
For these and other reasons, although the Buddha has no attachment to any dharmas, he still uses harsh words to teach and transform.

The Buddha does not allow bhiká¹£us to use the eight kinds of bowls means bowls made of gold, silver, and other precious materials. Because precious objects are coveted by people, they are difficult to obtain;
because of attachment, he does not allow the keeping of these precious objects, and one is not even allowed to lift them with one's hands;
Precious bowls are also not allowed to be kept, but if they are made into pure offerings, they can be used, because their price is not valuable.
Wooden bowls absorb dirt and grease, so they are not allowed to be kept because they are impure.
The three kinds of bowls do not have such problems.
Question:
Earthenware and iron bowls also absorb dirt and grease, no different from wooden bowls, so why are they allowed to be kept?
Answer:
Unbaked earthenware and iron bowls are also not allowed, because baked ones do not absorb dirt and grease.
Stone has coarse and fine, and the fine ones also do not absorb dirt and grease, so the World-Honored One himself kept them.
The reason why monks are not allowed to keep them is because they are heavy;
The Buddha's strength from nursing is superior to that of ten thousand white fragrant elephants, so he does not consider them heavy;
Out of compassion for the monks, he does not allow it.
Question:
The attendants RÄhula, Nanda, Åšroá¹‡akoá¹­iviá¹ƒÅ›a, NÄgasena, Ä€nanda, and others always followed the World-Honored One, holding their alms bowls. Why did he not have pity on them?
Answer:
Although the attendants held the Buddha's bowl, it was due to the Buddha's majestic power and also because they respected and revered the Buddha, so they did not feel it was heavy;
and also because Ä€nanda's physical strength was great.
Moreover, because fine stone bowls were difficult to obtain and coarse ones would absorb grease and dirt, they were not allowed to use them.
The Buddha's bowl was naturally produced on the four mountain peaks of the Four Heavenly Kings. Other people did not have such naturally produced bowls;
if they sought to make them, it was very difficult and would interfere with many things, so they were not allowed to use them.
Moreover, in order to distinguish the Buddha from his disciples, the Buddha used a stone bowl.
It is also like a king, who is respected by people, and his eating utensils are also different.
If someone sees the Buddha's different bowl, they will increase their respect and offerings, and their faith will become pure.
Question:
If the bowl should be different, why is the robe the same?
Answer:
The Buddha's robe is also different.
When the Buddha first attained enlightenment, he knew that KÄÅ›yapa's robe was suitable for the Buddha to wear. The price of KÄÅ›yapa's robe was worth 100,000 taels of gold.
Next, JÄ«vaka offered the Buddha a deep-red kÄpÄ«lava robe, also worth 100,000 taels of gold.
The Buddha instructed Ä€nanda to take the robe, cut it up, and make a saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä«. After it was made, the Buddha accepted it and wore it. This is the difference.
Question:
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us for this reason:

From today, if there are bhiká¹£us who single-mindedly seek nirvÄá¹‡a and turn their backs on the world, if they wish to wear it, they are allowed to wear a robe worth 100,000 taels of gold, and they are also allowed to eat food of a hundred flavors.
The robe is different and then allowed, but the bowl is not allowed alone?
Answer:
I have already explained the causes and conditions of the stone bowl, and I will now explain further.
The Buddha's bowl is not received from a person.
When the Buddha first attained enlightenment, he needed a vessel to eat. The Four Heavenly Kings knew the Buddha's thoughts and offered him four alms bowls.
The Dharma of the Buddhas of the three times is to accept the alms bowls offered by the Four Heavenly Kings.
At that time there was no Sangha yet, so how could it be said to be permitted?
If it were permitted later, no one would give stone bowls.
Moreover, JambudvÄ«pa does not like stone bowls, so no one would give them.
Furthermore, the Buddha said that bhiká¹£us should always conceal their merits. If they accepted stone bowls, people would say they obtained them from devas or nÄgas.
If people were made to make them, the craft would be difficult, and people might say:
This bhiká¹£u wants to equal the Buddha's merits.
The reason for permitting robes is that if someone said:
The Buddha, being in the Sangha, accepts the best robes offered by donors and wears them alone, while not permitting bhiká¹£us to do so,
therefore the Buddha permitted their use.
Bhiká¹£us also did not have any to use themselves, because donors were rare and obtaining them was difficult.
If a bhiká¹£u is impure, people will not give to him;
Pure bhiká¹£us, because of their few desires and contentment, do not become attached.
The Buddha cuts off people's doubts, so he allows them to wear robes;
There is no expectation in the alms bowl, so he does not allow it.
Question:
As it is said in the sÅ«tras, The Buddha's vajra body does not rely on food, why does he keep an alms bowl?
Answer:
There are two paths in the Buddha's teachings:
First, the path of the Å›rÄvakas, and second, the path of the Buddhas.
In the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas, the Buddha follows human dharmas and eats;
In the teachings of the MahÄyÄna, he manifests eating for the sake of people, but in reality he does not eat.
Question:
What is this skillful means?
Answer:
The Buddha wishes to save people, so he demonstrates practicing human dharmas.
If it were not so, people would consider the Buddha to be superhuman, and how could we practice his teachings?
Furthermore, there are people who attain liberation through giving. For their sake, the Buddha accepts their food and thinks like this:
By eating, I can benefit the Buddha's body.
The mind greatly rejoices.
Because of the joy, one faithfully accepts the Buddha's words.
It is like the lord of a great country. Even though the king does not need it, in order to embrace that person, he eats a little bit of food to make them happy.
For these and other causes and conditions, the Buddha manifests accepting food.
Question:
If the Buddha does not eat, where does what is accepted go?
Answer:
The Buddha's affairs are inconceivable, so this question should not be asked!

Furthermore, there are those who attain liberation by obtaining the Buddha's food, and there are those who attain liberation by hearing his voice, seeing his form, touching his body, or smelling his fragrance.
Those who attain liberation through food, the Buddha gives them food.
As the Sutra of the Secret Traces of Vajra says:
When the Buddha puts food in his mouth, there are gods seeking the Buddha's path who bring it to the ten directions and offer it.
Question:
If that is so, then it is said in the Sangha that there are no sentient beings who can eat the Buddha's food. What is the meaning of this?
Answer:
If the Buddha does not give it, there is no one who can eat it;
Now the Buddha offers it, so one can eat it.
How do we know this?
When the Buddha ate oats, he gave some to Ä€nanda;
Also, the Å›ramaá¹‡a ViÅ›ÄkhÄ offered delicious soup to the Buddha, and the Buddha gave the remaining soup to King BimbisÄra.
For this reason, we know that if the Buddha accepts and gives it, then one can eat it; if he does not give it, then one cannot digest it.
Furthermore, if food is prepared for the Buddha but he has not yet eaten it, then people cannot digest it;
If he has already eaten and there is leftover food, then the Buddha can give it and they can digest it.
For this reason, although he truly does not eat, in order to save people he manifests accepting food and keeping a bowl.
As for the Buddha did not answer the fourteen difficult questions, the Buddha has four kinds of answers:
First, definitive answers; second, analytical answers; third, counter-questioning answers; fourth, unanswered answers.
These fourteen difficult questions should be answered by remaining silent.
Moreover, if there is a matter that can benefit, then it is answered;
The questions asked by non-Buddhists are not for nirvana, and they increase confusion and doubt, so they are answered by remaining silent.
If it is known that there will definitely be benefits, it is answered by analysis;
If there will definitely be no benefit, it is left unanswered.
For this reason, it is known that the Buddha is a person of omniscience.
Furthermore, if the Buddha speaks of three kinds of dharmas:
Conditioned dharmas, unconditioned dharmas, and inexpressible dharmas, then he has already spoken of all dharmas.
Moreover, these non-Buddhists rely on the view of permanence and the view of annihilation, so they ask about permanence and annihilation;
Because the true nature does not exist, the Buddha does not answer.
Like the eternal characteristics and impermanent characteristics seen by non-Buddhists, this is not the case.
Why is it so?
Non-Buddhists grasp characteristics and are attached to permanence and cessation;
Although the Buddha speaks of the characteristics of permanence and impermanence, it is only for the sake of treating afflictions.
Furthermore, if someone says that what does not exist exists and what exists does not exist, such a person would be at fault. The Buddha does not answer and is therefore blameless.
Just as the sun shines on the world and cannot make the high become low or the low become high, it only illuminates;
The Buddha is also like this. He does not create anything in the dharmas. He says that what exists exists and that what does not exist does not exist.
As it is said:

Birth is a condition for old age and death, up to ignorance being a condition for the various formative factors. Whether Buddhas appear in the world or not, this principle of conditioned arising always abides in the world;
The Buddhas appear in the world to reveal this Dharma to sentient beings.
Furthermore, if one answers with permanence or cessation, one would be at fault.
It is like asking:
What is the child of a barren woman and a eunuch like in terms of length, shortness, blackness, and whiteness?
This question should not be answered.

The fourteen difficult questions are also like this. It is only because of the basis of permanence and cessation that the question is asked. Since there is no permanence or cessation, the Buddha does not answer.
For these various reasons, the Buddha does not answer the fourteen difficult questions, and there is no fault.

The Buddha speaks of the existence of a self in some places and the non-existence of a self in other places means that if a person understands the meaning of the Buddha's teachings and knows the provisional names, he says there is a self;
if a person does not understand the meaning of the Buddha's teachings and does not know the provisional names, he says there is no self.
Furthermore, the Buddha speaks for sentient beings who are about to fall into the view of annihilation, saying:
There is a self that experiences the retribution of sins and merits in the next world.
If a person is about to fall into the view of permanence, he is told:
There is no self, no doer, no experiencer. Apart from the five aggregates, there is no other independent entity.
Question:
If that is so, then what is real?
Answer:
The absence of self is real.
As stated in the Dharma seal:
All conditioned phenomena are impermanent, all dharmas are without self, and quiescent extinction is the peace of nirvana.
The Dharma seal is called the true nature of all dharmas.
If a person's wholesome roots are not yet mature and their wisdom is not sharp, the Buddha does not teach them this profound teaching on no-self;
if he were to teach it, sentient beings would then fall into the view of annihilation.
Question:
If that is so, then as stated in the Questions of KÄÅ›yapa, the Buddha said:
Self is one extreme, no-self is another extreme. Apart from these two extremes is the middle way.
Now, how can it be said that the absence of self is real and the existence of self is taught as a skillful means?
Answer:
Explaining the non-existence of self has two aspects:
First, grasping the characteristics of non-self and being attached to non-self;
Second, destroying the self without grasping non-self, and not being attached to non-self, naturally letting go.
As explained earlier, non-self is an extreme;
The later explanation of non-self is the middle way.
Furthermore, the Buddha explains the existence and non-existence of self for two reasons:
First, using conventional expressions, there is a self; second, using the ultimate truth, there is no self.
Explaining the existence and non-existence of self in this way is without fault.
The Buddha explains the existence of all dharmas in some places and the non-existence of all dharmas in other places.
Question:
One should not explain existence and non-existence separately.
Existence is the existence of self;
Non-existence is the non-existence of self;
Why explain it again?
Answer:
This is not so!
The Buddha's teachings have two kinds of emptiness:
First, the emptiness of sentient beings, second, the emptiness of phenomena.
Explaining non-self shows the emptiness of sentient beings;
Explaining the non-existence of phenomena shows the emptiness of phenomena.
Explaining the existence of self shows the knowledge of provisional names and forms, and those who are not attached to self are said to have a self;

Those who are attached to the characteristics of self within the five aggregates, in order to break this attachment to self, it is said that there are only five aggregates, impermanent, suffering, empty, and selfless, and the cessation of nirvana is called existence.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of views of annihilation:

First, those who do not believe in the afterlife and receiving the suffering and happiness of retribution, for them it is said that there is a self that goes from this world to the next world and receives the fruits of retribution.
Second, those who believe that all phenomena are empty and non-existent, and are attached to this wrong view;
For the sake of these sentient beings, it is said that there are all phenomena, namely conditioned and unconditioned dharmas.
Furthermore, for sentient beings with dull faculties, it is said that there is no self;
For those with sharp faculties and deep wisdom, it is taught that all dharmas are ultimately empty.
Why is this?
If there is no self, then all dharmas are abandoned. As it is said:
If one clearly understands non-self, then for such a person,
Hearing of dharmas, one is not delighted; hearing of no dharmas, one is not worried.
The teaching of self is the basis for all dharmas;
If one teaches non-self, then all dharmas have no basis.
Furthermore, the Buddha's teachings are of two kinds:
If taught clearly, it is said that all dharmas are empty;
If taught skillfully, it is said that there is no self.
These two kinds of teachings all enter into the characteristics of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
For this reason, the Buddha's sÅ«tras say:
The path leading to nirvÄá¹‡a is all of one direction, there is no different path.
Furthermore, the existence of self and existence of dharmas are often taught to laypeople, along with parents, sin, merit, large and small karmic retributions.
Why is this?
Because laypeople often do not seek nirvana, but are attached to the fruits and retributions of the next world.
For those who have left the household life, the Buddha often teaches no-self and no dharmas.
Why is this?
Because those who have left the household life often turn towards nirvana.
Those who seek nirvana do not accept any dharmas, and thus naturally extinguish, which is nirvana.
Furthermore, there are people whose faculties such as faith are not yet perfected, so they first seek to attain something and then are able to let go;
For the sake of such people, the Buddha teaches the cultivation of wholesome dharmas and the abandonment of unwholesome dharmas.
There are people whose faculties such as faith are perfected, so they do not seek to attain anything in regard to dharmas, but only seek the path to liberation from birth and death;
For the sake of such people, the Buddha teaches the emptiness and non-existence of all dharmas.
Both of these are true.
Just as the ring finger is both long and short - when compared to the middle finger it is short, when compared to the little finger it is long, and both long and short are real;
The same is true of speaking of existence and non-existence.
Speaking of existence is sometimes conventional and sometimes ultimate;
Speaking of non-existence is sometimes conventional and sometimes ultimate.
The Buddha's teachings on the existence of a self and the non-existence of a self are all real.
Question:
If both of these are real, why does the Buddha praise emptiness so much and criticize existence?
Answer:
Emptiness and non-existence is the Dharma treasury of the Buddhas and sages of the ten directions, as stated in the chapter on entrusting in the Prajnaparamita Sutra:
The perfection of wisdom is the Dharma treasury of the Buddhas of the three times and ten directions.
The perfection of wisdom is precisely the emptiness of non-existence.
The Buddha sometimes speaks of the existence of dharmas in order to teach and transform sentient beings, but in the end they will all enter the treasury of non-existence.
Question:
If that is so, why does the Prajnaparamita Sutra say, If one contemplates the emptiness and non-existence of the five aggregates, it is not the Way?
Answer:
In the Prajnaparamita Sutra, both existence and non-existence are said to be non-existent.
As the Sutra of the Long-nailed Brahman explains, there are three kinds of wrong views:
First, everything exists; second, everything does not exist; third, half exists and half does not exist.
The Buddha told the Long-nailed Brahman:
This view that everything exists is bound by desire, anger, and delusion.
The view that everything does not exist is not bound because it is not stained, not angry, and not deluded.
As for half existing and half not existing, what exists is the same as what exists above and is bound;
What does not exist is the same as what does not exist above and is not bound.
Among the three kinds of views, the noble disciples think like this:

If I accept the view of the existence of everything, then I will argue with two kinds of people, namely those who say everything is non-existent and those who say half exists and half does not exist.ğŸ”½If I accept the view of the non-existence of everything, I will also argue with two kinds of people, namely those who say everything exists and those who say half exists and half does not exist.
If I accept the view of half existing and half not existing, I will also argue with two kinds of people, namely those who say everything is non-existent and those who say everything exists.
Because of arguing, we slander each other; because of slandering, we are troubled;

Because of seeing this as arguing, slandering, and troubling, we abandon this view of non-existence, and do not accept the remaining views either. Because of not accepting, we then enter the path.ğŸ”½If one does not cling to the emptiness of all dharmas, the mind does not give rise to arguments, but only eliminates the afflictions. This is called true wisdom.
If one grasps the characteristics of the emptiness of all dharmas and gives rise to arguments, and does not eliminate the afflictions, relying on this wisdom, this is not true wisdom.
As the Buddha said, he speaks in order to liberate sentient beings, and nothing he says is not true;
It's just that sentient beings have attachment and non-attachment, so there is truth and falsehood.
For these various reasons, the Buddha's physical, verbal, and mental actions have no faults.
Therefore, it is said that the Buddha's physical, verbal, and mental actions are preceded by knowledge and then carried out in accordance with wisdom.
Question:

Previously, it was said that there are no faults in the body, no faults in speech, and no faults in memory, and now it is said that the physical, verbal, and mental actions follow wisdom. What is the difference in meaning?
Answer:
The previous three kinds of faults do not discuss the causes and conditions;
Now, the causes and conditions are discussed, because following wisdom does not lead to faults.
If one does not first consider and then engage in physical, verbal, and mental actions, then there will be faults;
The Buddha first uses wisdom to engage in physical, verbal, and mental actions, so there are no faults.
Furthermore, the Buddha has accomplished three kinds of pure karma, three kinds of tranquil karma, and three kinds of karma without protection.
Some people have doubts and say:
For what causes and conditions has the Buddha accomplished such karma?
Therefore the Buddha said:
All my bodily, verbal, and mental actions are first done with wisdom, and then I act in accordance with wisdom.

The Buddha knows the past, future, and present with wisdom, and penetrates them without obstruction means that these three kinds of wisdom penetrate the three times without obstruction, so the three karmas act in accordance with wisdom.
Question:
The dharmas of the past have already ceased and are no longer existent;
The dharmas of the future have not yet come and are not yet born, not yet combined;
The present, even for a single moment, has no time of abiding. How can one know the three times and penetrate them without obstruction?
Answer:
The Buddha said that the past, future, and present are unobstructed, how can these words be false?
Furthermore, if there is no past or future, and only the present for an instant, the Buddha would also not be able to accomplish immeasurable merits.
If the ten kinds of cognition are the ten powers, then at that time one mind cannot have ten cognitions.
If so, then the Buddha would also not be able to possess the ten powers.
For this reason, we know that there is past and future.
Question:
If the past, future, and present all exist, then what is nonexistent?
The Buddha spoke of the four truths, and the truth of suffering observes the characteristics of impermanence, etc. Impermanence is called arising, ceasing, decaying, and being unobtainable;
If past dharmas really exist now, they cannot be called impermanent, decaying, or unobtainable.
Furthermore, if the past, future, and present all exist, then one would fall into eternalism.
Why is it so?
This dharma definitely exists in the future, and then comes to the present, and from the present it moves into the past;
just as a person moves from one room to another, it is not called losing the person?
Answer:
If it is not lost, what is the problem?
Question:
If there is no impermanence, there is no sin, no merit, no birth, no death, no bondage, and no liberation.
Sin refers to the ten unwholesome paths of action such as killing. If there is no impermanence, there is no sin such as killing.
As it is said in the Distinguishing Wrong Views:
The sword passes through the seven parts of the body, causing no harm.
Merit refers to the ten wholesome paths of action such as not killing.
Impermanence refers to the discrimination of birth and death;
if there is no impermanence, there is also no birth and death, and also no bondage and no liberation.
There are immeasurable faults like this!
Answer:
The three time periods of all dharmas each have their own characteristics:
Past dharmas have the characteristics of the past, future dharmas have the characteristics of the future, and present dharmas have the characteristics of the present.
If the past and future had the characteristics of the present, there would be this difficulty;
but now the past, future, and present each have their own characteristics.
Furthermore, if the past and future really do not exist, then there would also be no precepts for renouncing the world.
Why is this?
If one abides in a present evil mind and the past also has no precepts, then one is not a bhiká¹£u.
Moreover, when the mind of an arhat is in the mundane, at that time one should be an ordinary person!
Because there is no past, future, or present path.
In this way, there are also no such sins as the five heinous crimes.
Why is this?
These five heinous crimes are past, and when one dies they enter hell. These five heinous crimes are future, and because there is no karma there is no retribution;
If there is no past, then there are no heinous crimes;
if there are no heinous crimes, then how can there be any other crimes?
Merit is also like this.
If there were no sin or merit, this would be a wrong view, no different from that of animals!
Moreover, I do not say:
The past and future exist in the same way as the present.
I say:
Although the past has ceased, one can give rise to recollection and it can give rise to mental states.
Just as yesterday's fire has gone out, today one can give rise to recollection and remembrance, but one cannot say that because of recollection and remembrance the fire then exists.
If one sees stacked firewood, one knows that fire will occur, and also gives rise to mental recollection;
tomorrow's fire is like the past fire, but one cannot say that because of the present thought of fire the fire then exists;
future events are also like this.
Although the present mind does not abide for a single moment, because it arises in continuity, it can know all dharmas.

Internally, using the present mind as the cause, externally, using all dharmas as conditions, within this cause and condition, consciousness arises, using consciousness to freely know past, future, and present dharmas;
But one cannot know one's own present mind and mental factors, one can know the rest.
Question:

In the chapter on the characteristics of suchness in the Prajnaparamita Sutra, the three times have one characteristic, which is no characteristic. How can it be said that the Buddha's wisdom knows the three times and penetrates them without obstruction?
Answer:
The Buddhas have two ways of teaching the Dharma:
